terms.definition: Annual Percentage Yield (APY) represents the real rate of return earned on an investment, taking into account the effect of compounding interest. In DeFi, APY shows how much you can earn annually from lending, liquidity providing, or staking.
terms.short_definition: The annual return on investment including compound interest effects
terms.example: A liquidity pool offering 15% APY means your initial investment would grow by 15% over a year with compounding.

common_questions.question: What is the difference between APR and APY?
common_questions.answer: APR shows simple interest while APY includes compounding effects. APY is typically higher and more accurate for DeFi yields.

related_articles.title: How to make DeFinancial products work for you
related_articles.description: A complete guide to DeFi yield strategies and understanding returns

terms.definition: Impermanent loss occurs when providing liquidity to automated market makers (AMMs) and the price ratio of your deposited tokens changes compared to when you deposited them. The loss is 'impermanent' because it only becomes permanent when you withdraw your liquidity.
terms.short_definition: Temporary loss experienced by liquidity providers when token prices diverge
terms.example: If you provide ETH/USDC liquidity at 1 ETH = $2000, but ETH rises to $3000, you'll have less ETH and more USDC when you withdraw, missing some of ETH's gains.

common_questions.question: How can I minimize impermanent loss?
common_questions.answer: Choose stable pairs, use concentrated liquidity ranges carefully, or consider single-sided staking instead of providing liquidity to volatile pairs.

related_articles.title: How to make DeFinancial products work for you
related_articles.description: Understanding LP risks and DeFi yield strategies

terms.definition: Yield farming is the practice of moving crypto assets between different DeFi protocols to maximize returns. Farmers typically provide liquidity, lend assets, or stake tokens to earn yields in the form of interest, fees, or reward tokens.
terms.short_definition: Strategy of maximizing returns by moving assets between DeFi protocols
terms.example: A yield farmer might provide ETH/USDC liquidity on Uniswap, stake the LP tokens on a rewards platform, and use the earned tokens in another protocol for additional yields.

common_questions.question: Is yield farming profitable?
common_questions.answer: Yield farming can be profitable but involves significant risks including smart contract vulnerabilities, impermanent loss, and high gas fees. Success requires careful research and risk management.

related_articles.title: The DeFinancial Farming Toolbox
related_articles.description: Complete guide to yield farming strategies, tools and best practices

related_articles.title: Vaults: DeFi Investing Streamlined?
related_articles.description: Understanding automated yield strategies and vault mechanisms

terms.definition: Liquidity mining is a mechanism where users provide liquidity to decentralized exchanges or lending protocols in exchange for token rewards. It's used by protocols to bootstrap liquidity and distribute governance tokens to users.
terms.short_definition: Earning token rewards by providing liquidity to DeFi protocols
terms.example: Compound distributes COMP tokens to users who supply assets to their lending pools, incentivizing liquidity provision.

common_questions.question: How long do liquidity mining programs last?
common_questions.answer: Programs vary widely, from weeks to years. Many protocols adjust rewards based on protocol needs and governance decisions.

related_articles.title: The DeFinancial Farming Toolbox
related_articles.description: Understanding liquidity mining programs and reward mechanisms

terms.definition: An Automated Market Maker (AMM) is a type of decentralized exchange protocol that relies on mathematical formulas to price assets rather than order books. AMMs enable permissionless trading by using liquidity pools where users can swap tokens automatically.
terms.short_definition: Decentralized exchange using mathematical formulas for pricing instead of order books
terms.example: Uniswap is an AMM where users can swap ETH for USDC directly from liquidity pools without needing a counterparty.

common_questions.question: How does an AMM determine prices?
common_questions.answer: AMMs use algorithms like x*y=k (constant product) to automatically adjust prices based on supply and demand in liquidity pools.

related_articles.title: How to make DeFinancial products work for you
related_articles.description: Understanding AMM-based DeFi strategies and automated trading

terms.definition: A Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) is a blockchain-based organization governed by smart contracts and token holders rather than traditional management structures. Members vote on proposals using governance tokens to make decisions about the protocol's future.
terms.short_definition: Blockchain-based organization governed by token holders and smart contracts
terms.example: MakerDAO governs the Maker protocol, where MKR token holders vote on stability fees, collateral types, and other protocol parameters.

common_questions.question: How do I participate in DAO governance?
common_questions.answer: Hold governance tokens, stay informed about proposals, and vote on decisions that affect the protocol's future.

terms.definition: A smart contract is a self-executing contract with terms directly written into code. In DeFi, smart contracts automatically execute transactions when predetermined conditions are met, eliminating the need for intermediaries.
terms.short_definition: Self-executing code that automatically enforces contract terms on blockchain
terms.example: A lending protocol's smart contract automatically liquidates undercollateralized positions without human intervention.

common_questions.question: Can smart contracts be changed after deployment?
common_questions.answer: Most smart contracts are immutable once deployed, though some include upgrade mechanisms controlled by governance or admin keys.

terms.definition: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) refers to a blockchain-based form of finance that recreates and improves traditional financial systems using smart contracts, removing intermediaries like banks and brokers. DeFi applications run on public blockchains and are accessible to anyone.
terms.short_definition: Blockchain-based financial system operating without traditional intermediaries
terms.example: You can lend USDC on Compound, borrow against ETH on Aave, and swap tokens on Uniswap - all without banks or brokers.

common_questions.question: What are the main advantages of DeFi over traditional finance?
common_questions.answer: 24/7 accessibility, permissionless access, transparency, programmability, and typically better yields for users.

related_articles.title: How to make DeFinancial products work for you
related_articles.description: Comprehensive guide to DeFi strategies and financial products

related_articles.title: The DeFinancial Farming Toolbox
related_articles.description: Essential tools and strategies for DeFi yield farming

related_articles.title: Vaults: DeFi Investing Streamlined?
related_articles.description: Understanding automated DeFi investment strategies

terms.definition: A stablecoin is a cryptocurrency designed to maintain a stable value relative to a reference asset, usually the US Dollar. Stablecoins provide the benefits of crypto (fast, borderless transfers) while minimizing price volatility.
terms.short_definition: Cryptocurrency designed to maintain stable value relative to a reference asset
terms.example: USDC maintains a $1 value backed by dollar reserves, while DAI is decentralized and backed by crypto collateral.

common_questions.question: What's the difference between centralized and decentralized stablecoins?
common_questions.answer: Centralized stablecoins like USDC are backed by fiat reserves, while decentralized ones like DAI use crypto collateral and algorithms.

related_articles.title: The Maurauder's Map of Decentralized Stablecoins
related_articles.description: Comprehensive analysis of decentralized stablecoin mechanisms and designs

related_articles.title: Can Aave's GHO stablecoin help the protocol further grow?
related_articles.description: Deep dive into GHO's design and stablecoin economics

terms.definition: A liquidity pool is a collection of funds locked in a smart contract that enables decentralized trading, lending, and other DeFi functions. Users contribute assets to pools and earn fees from trades or interest from loans.
terms.short_definition: Smart contract containing funds that enable decentralized trading and lending
terms.example: The ETH/USDC pool on Uniswap contains both ETH and USDC, allowing users to swap between these tokens while LPs earn trading fees.

common_questions.question: How do liquidity providers earn money?
common_questions.answer: LPs earn trading fees (typically 0.3%) from every swap, plus potential reward tokens from liquidity mining programs.

related_articles.title: Staying Ahead of the Curve: the shift from Liquidity Mining to Liquidity Shaping
related_articles.description: Advanced liquidity pool management and liquidity shaping strategies

related_articles.title: The DeFinancial Farming Toolbox
related_articles.description: Practical guide to using liquidity pools for yield farming

terms.definition: Slippage refers to the difference between the expected price of a trade and the actual executed price. It occurs when there's insufficient liquidity or high volatility, causing the price to move unfavorably during trade execution.
terms.short_definition: Difference between expected and actual trade execution price
terms.example: You try to buy $10,000 worth of a token at $100, but due to slippage, you end up paying an average of $102 per token.

common_questions.question: How can I minimize slippage?
common_questions.answer: Trade smaller amounts, use liquid pairs, set appropriate slippage tolerance, or use aggregators that find the best routes.

terms.definition: Governance tokens give holders voting rights on protocol decisions such as parameter changes, upgrades, and treasury management. They represent democratic control over decentralized protocols and often appreciate with protocol success.
terms.short_definition: Token that provides voting rights on protocol governance decisions
terms.example: UNI token holders can vote on Uniswap protocol upgrades, fee structures, and treasury spending proposals.

common_questions.question: Do governance tokens have monetary value?
common_questions.answer: Yes, they trade on markets and derive value from the protocol's success and potential future cash flows or benefits.

related_articles.title: The DeFinancial Farming Toolbox
related_articles.description: Understanding governance tokens as rewards in liquidity mining programs

related_articles.title: Staying Ahead of the Curve: the shift from Liquidity Mining to Liquidity Shaping
related_articles.description: Advanced governance token models like veMAV and vote-escrow mechanisms

terms.definition: Flash loans are uncollateralized loans that must be borrowed and repaid within the same transaction block. They enable complex DeFi strategies like arbitrage, liquidations, and collateral swaps without requiring initial capital.
terms.short_definition: Instant uncollateralized loan that must be repaid in the same transaction
terms.example: A trader uses a flash loan to borrow 1000 ETH, arbitrage price differences between exchanges, and repay the loan plus fees - all in one transaction.

common_questions.question: What happens if I can't repay a flash loan?
common_questions.answer: The entire transaction reverts, meaning you get your original funds back but pay gas fees for the failed transaction.

terms.definition: Ethereum is a decentralized, open-source blockchain platform that enables the creation of smart contracts and decentralized applications (dApps). It's the primary blockchain for DeFi applications due to its programmability and established ecosystem.
terms.short_definition: Programmable blockchain platform that powers most DeFi applications
terms.example: Most DeFi protocols like Uniswap, Aave, and Compound are built on Ethereum's blockchain.

common_questions.question: Why is Ethereum so important for DeFi?
common_questions.answer: Ethereum's programmable smart contracts enable complex financial applications, and it has the largest DeFi ecosystem and liquidity.

terms.definition: Layer 2 solutions are secondary frameworks built on top of existing blockchains to improve scalability and reduce costs. They process transactions off the main chain while inheriting its security.
terms.short_definition: Scaling solutions built on top of blockchains to reduce fees and increase speed
terms.example: Polygon, Arbitrum, and Optimism are Layer 2 solutions that offer cheaper DeFi transactions than Ethereum mainnet.

common_questions.question: Are Layer 2 solutions as secure as Ethereum?
common_questions.answer: They inherit Ethereum's security but may have additional risks depending on their specific implementation and centralization level.

terms.definition: A bridge is a protocol that allows users to transfer assets and data between different blockchains or Layer 2 solutions. Bridges enable interoperability in the multi-chain DeFi ecosystem.
terms.short_definition: Protocol enabling asset transfers between different blockchains
terms.example: You can use a bridge to move ETH from Ethereum mainnet to Polygon, or USDC from Ethereum to Arbitrum.

common_questions.question: Are bridges safe to use?
common_questions.answer: Bridges carry risks as they're complex smart contracts. Use well-audited, established bridges and never invest more than you can afford to lose.

terms.definition: An oracle is a service that provides real-world data to blockchain applications. In DeFi, price oracles supply current asset prices for lending protocols, derivatives, and other applications that need off-chain data.
terms.short_definition: Service that provides real-world data like prices to blockchain applications
terms.example: Chainlink oracles provide ETH/USD prices to lending protocols to determine collateral values and liquidation thresholds.

common_questions.question: Why can't smart contracts get price data directly?
common_questions.answer: Blockchains can't access external data by design. Oracles act as bridges to bring real-world information on-chain securely.

terms.definition: MEV refers to the maximum profit that can be extracted by reordering, including, or excluding transactions within a block. This includes front-running, sandwich attacks, and arbitrage opportunities.
terms.short_definition: Profit extracted by manipulating transaction ordering in blocks
terms.example: A bot sees your large DEX trade, places a buy order before yours and a sell order after, profiting from the price impact you create.

common_questions.question: How can I protect myself from MEV?
common_questions.answer: Use private mempools, set appropriate slippage tolerance, or use MEV-protected trading interfaces.

terms.definition: A DEX aggregator is a service that sources liquidity from multiple decentralized exchanges to find the best prices and lowest slippage for trades. They optimize routing to minimize trading costs.
terms.short_definition: Service that finds the best prices across multiple DEXs for trades
terms.example: 1inch aggregates prices from Uniswap, SushiSwap, and other DEXs to execute your trade at the best possible rate.

common_questions.question: Do aggregators always give better prices?
common_questions.answer: Usually yes, but consider gas costs. For small trades, the gas cost of complex routing might outweigh savings.

terms.definition: A multisig wallet requires multiple signatures (keys) to authorize transactions, providing enhanced security over single-key wallets. Commonly used for protocol governance and treasury management.
terms.short_definition: Wallet requiring multiple signatures to authorize transactions
terms.example: A 3-of-5 multisig requires at least 3 out of 5 designated signers to approve any transaction.

common_questions.question: What happens if multisig signers are unavailable?
common_questions.answer: If you can't reach the minimum threshold, funds become inaccessible. This is why backup plans and trusted signers are crucial.

terms.definition: Gas is the unit that measures the computational effort required to execute operations on Ethereum. Users pay gas fees to miners/validators to process their transactions.
terms.short_definition: Fee paid to execute transactions on Ethereum blockchain
terms.example: A simple ETH transfer might cost 21,000 gas units, while complex DeFi interactions can cost 200,000+ gas units.

common_questions.question: Why are gas fees so high sometimes?
common_questions.answer: Gas fees increase with network demand. During busy periods, users compete by paying higher fees to get their transactions processed faster.

terms.definition: ERC-20 is a technical standard for fungible tokens on the Ethereum blockchain. It defines a common interface that allows tokens to be easily integrated with wallets, exchanges, and other applications.
terms.short_definition: Standard for creating fungible tokens on Ethereum
terms.example: USDC, DAI, UNI, and most DeFi tokens are ERC-20 tokens that follow this standard.

common_questions.question: Can I use ERC-20 tokens on other blockchains?
common_questions.answer: Not directly, but you can bridge them to other chains or use wrapped versions that follow other standards.

terms.definition: A wrapped token represents another cryptocurrency on a different blockchain. It's backed 1:1 by the original asset held in custody, enabling cross-chain functionality.
terms.short_definition: Token representing another cryptocurrency on a different blockchain
terms.example: WETH (Wrapped ETH) allows ETH to be used in ERC-20 contracts, while WBTC brings Bitcoin functionality to Ethereum.

common_questions.question: Is a wrapped token the same as the original?
common_questions.answer: Functionally similar but technically different. They should maintain 1:1 value but carry additional risks from the wrapping mechanism.

terms.definition: The mempool is a waiting area for unconfirmed transactions on a blockchain network. Transactions sit in the mempool until miners or validators include them in a block.
terms.short_definition: Waiting area for unconfirmed blockchain transactions
terms.example: When you submit a transaction, it first goes to the mempool where MEV bots can see it before it's included in a block.

common_questions.question: Why is my transaction stuck in the mempool?
common_questions.answer: Usually due to low gas fees. Miners prioritize higher-fee transactions, so yours waits until network congestion decreases or you increase the fee.

terms.definition: Validators are network participants who validate transactions and create new blocks in Proof of Stake blockchains. They stake tokens as collateral and earn rewards for honest behavior.
terms.short_definition: Network participants who validate transactions in Proof of Stake systems
terms.example: Ethereum 2.0 validators stake 32 ETH to participate in consensus and earn staking rewards.

common_questions.question: What is slashing in staking?
common_questions.answer: Slashing is a penalty where validators lose part of their staked tokens for malicious behavior or prolonged downtime.

terms.definition: A consensus mechanism is the method by which a blockchain network agrees on the validity of transactions and the state of the ledger. Common types include Proof of Work and Proof of Stake.
terms.short_definition: Method for blockchain networks to agree on transaction validity
terms.example: Bitcoin uses Proof of Work consensus while Ethereum transitioned to Proof of Stake for better energy efficiency.

common_questions.question: Why did Ethereum switch from Proof of Work to Proof of Stake?
common_questions.answer: For better energy efficiency, improved security, and to enable features like sharding for better scalability.

terms.definition: A block is a collection of transactions that are bundled together and added to the blockchain. Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, creating an immutable chain.
terms.short_definition: Collection of transactions bundled together on a blockchain
terms.example: An Ethereum block contains multiple transactions and is produced approximately every 12 seconds.

common_questions.question: How many confirmations do I need?
common_questions.answer: For high-value transactions, wait for 6+ confirmations on Ethereum. For smaller amounts, 1-3 confirmations are usually sufficient.

terms.definition: Annual Percentage Rate (APR) represents the simple annual interest rate without compounding effects. In DeFi, APR shows the base yield before considering compound interest.
terms.short_definition: Simple annual interest rate without compounding effects
terms.example: A lending pool offering 10% APR means you earn 10% per year in simple interest.

terms.definition: Lending in DeFi allows users to lend their crypto assets to earn interest. Smart contracts automatically manage the lending process, eliminating the need for traditional intermediaries.
terms.short_definition: Earning interest by lending crypto assets through smart contracts
terms.example: You can lend USDC on Aave to earn interest paid by borrowers who need liquidity.

terms.definition: Borrowing in DeFi allows users to borrow crypto assets by providing collateral. This enables leverage, liquidity access, and various trading strategies without selling existing holdings.
terms.short_definition: Obtaining crypto loans by providing collateral to smart contracts
terms.example: You can borrow USDC against your ETH collateral on Compound to maintain ETH exposure while accessing liquidity.

terms.definition: Collateral is an asset pledged as security for a loan. In DeFi, users deposit collateral to borrow other assets, with smart contracts automatically managing the collateral and liquidation process.
terms.short_definition: Assets deposited as security to back a loan
terms.example: To borrow $1000 USDC, you might deposit $1500 worth of ETH as collateral to maintain a safe collateralization ratio.

terms.definition: LTV ratio represents the percentage of collateral value that can be borrowed. A lower LTV means more conservative lending, while higher LTV increases liquidation risk.
terms.short_definition: Percentage of collateral value that can be borrowed
terms.example: With 75% LTV, you can borrow up to $750 against $1000 of collateral.

terms.definition: Liquidation occurs when a borrower's collateral value falls below the required threshold, triggering automatic sale of collateral to repay the loan and protect lenders.
terms.short_definition: Automatic sale of collateral when loan becomes undercollateralized
terms.example: If your ETH collateral drops in value and your loan becomes undercollateralized, the protocol will liquidate your ETH to repay the loan.

terms.definition: A vault is an automated DeFi strategy that pools user funds and deploys them across various protocols to maximize yields. Vaults handle the complexity of yield farming automatically.
terms.short_definition: Automated strategy that pools funds to maximize yields across DeFi protocols
terms.example: Yearn Finance vaults automatically move your funds between different protocols to find the highest yields.

terms.definition: Staking involves locking tokens to support blockchain operations or protocol functions in exchange for rewards. This includes validator staking and DeFi protocol staking.
terms.short_definition: Locking tokens to earn rewards by supporting network or protocol operations
terms.example: You can stake ETH to become a validator and earn staking rewards, or stake protocol tokens to earn governance tokens.

terms.definition: Auto-compounding automatically reinvests earned rewards back into the original investment, maximizing returns through compound interest without manual intervention.
terms.short_definition: Automatic reinvestment of rewards to maximize compound returns
terms.example: A yield vault auto-compounds by automatically selling earned tokens and buying more of the deposit token to increase your position.

terms.definition: LP tokens are issued to liquidity providers as proof of their contribution to a liquidity pool. These tokens represent the provider's share of the pool and can be redeemed for the underlying assets plus earned fees.
terms.short_definition: Tokens representing a user's share in a liquidity pool
terms.example: When you provide ETH and USDC to a Uniswap pool, you receive ETH-USDC LP tokens that represent your stake in the pool.

terms.definition: Synthetic assets are blockchain-based derivatives that track the price of real-world assets like stocks, commodities, or currencies without requiring ownership of the underlying asset.
terms.short_definition: Blockchain tokens that track the price of real-world assets
terms.example: Synthetix offers synthetic Tesla stock (sTSLA) that tracks Tesla's price, allowing DeFi users to gain exposure to traditional assets.

terms.definition: Rebase tokens automatically adjust their total supply to maintain a target price. The number of tokens you hold changes, but your proportional share of the total supply remains constant.
terms.short_definition: Token with elastic supply that adjusts to maintain price stability
terms.example: AMPL (Ampleforth) increases or decreases all holders' token balances daily based on price deviation from $1.

terms.definition: Utility tokens provide holders with access to specific products, services, or functionalities within a protocol or ecosystem. They're not primarily designed as investments but as functional tools.
terms.short_definition: Token providing access to protocol features or services
terms.example: BNB is used to pay reduced trading fees on Binance exchange, while LINK is used to pay Chainlink oracle services.

terms.definition: NFTs are unique digital tokens that represent ownership of specific digital or physical items. Unlike fungible tokens, each NFT is distinct and cannot be exchanged on a one-to-one basis.
terms.short_definition: Unique digital tokens representing ownership of specific items
terms.example: An NFT might represent ownership of digital art, in-game items, or even real estate deeds on the blockchain.

terms.definition: ERC-721 is the technical standard for non-fungible tokens (NFTs) on Ethereum. It defines how to create unique, indivisible tokens that can represent ownership of digital or physical assets.
terms.short_definition: Standard for creating non-fungible tokens on Ethereum
terms.example: CryptoKitties and most NFT collections follow the ERC-721 standard to ensure compatibility with wallets and marketplaces.

terms.definition: Token burning permanently removes tokens from circulation by sending them to an unrecoverable address. This reduces total supply and can increase the value of remaining tokens.
terms.short_definition: Permanent removal of tokens from circulation
terms.example: Binance regularly burns BNB tokens to reduce supply, while Ethereum burns ETH through EIP-1559's base fee mechanism.

terms.definition: Tokenomics refers to the economic design and mechanics of a cryptocurrency token, including supply distribution, inflation/deflation mechanisms, utility, and incentive structures.
terms.short_definition: Economic design and mechanics of a cryptocurrency token
terms.example: Bitcoin's tokenomics include a fixed 21 million supply cap, halving events every 4 years, and mining rewards as incentives.

terms.definition: Vesting is the gradual release of tokens over time according to a predetermined schedule. It prevents immediate selling and aligns long-term interests of team members and investors.
terms.short_definition: Gradual release of tokens over time according to a schedule
terms.example: Team tokens might vest over 4 years with a 1-year cliff, meaning no tokens are released for the first year, then 25% each year after.

terms.definition: An airdrop is the free distribution of tokens to wallet addresses, usually to reward early users, increase adoption, or distribute governance tokens to decentralize control.
terms.short_definition: Free distribution of tokens to wallet addresses
terms.example: Uniswap airdropped 400 UNI tokens to every wallet that had used the protocol before September 2020.

terms.definition: A whitelist is a list of approved addresses that are allowed to participate in token sales, airdrops, or access specific protocol features before public availability.
terms.short_definition: List of approved addresses for early access to token events
terms.example: Many NFT projects create whitelists for early supporters to mint before the public sale.

terms.definition: Market capitalization is the total value of a cryptocurrency, calculated by multiplying the current price by the circulating supply. It's used to measure and compare the size of different projects.
terms.short_definition: Total value of a cryptocurrency (price  circulating supply)
terms.example: If a token trades at $10 with 1 million tokens in circulation, its market cap is $10 million.

terms.definition: Circulating supply refers to the number of tokens that are publicly available and actively trading in the market, excluding locked, reserved, or burned tokens.
terms.short_definition: Number of tokens publicly available and actively trading
terms.example: A project might have a total supply of 100 million tokens, but only 60 million in circulating supply due to team locks and reserves.

terms.definition: Total supply is the amount of tokens that currently exist, including all minted tokens minus any that have been burned. It includes both circulating and locked tokens.
terms.short_definition: Total number of tokens that currently exist
terms.example: Ethereum's total supply changes constantly as new ETH is minted for staking rewards and burned through transaction fees.

terms.definition: Maximum supply is the theoretical upper limit of tokens that can ever exist for a cryptocurrency. Once reached, no new tokens can be created.
terms.short_definition: Maximum number of tokens that can ever exist
terms.example: Bitcoin has a maximum supply of 21 million BTC, while Ethereum currently has no maximum supply limit.

terms.definition: Arbitrage is the practice of simultaneously buying and selling identical assets on different markets to profit from price differences. In DeFi, bots exploit price gaps between DEXs or CEXs.
terms.short_definition: Profiting from price differences of identical assets across markets
terms.example: If ETH trades at $2000 on Uniswap and $2005 on SushiSwap, an arbitrageur buys on Uniswap and sells on SushiSwap for $5 profit per ETH.

terms.definition: Price impact measures how much a trade moves the market price of an asset. Large trades in illiquid pools cause significant price impact, leading to unfavorable execution prices.
terms.short_definition: How much a trade moves the market price of an asset
terms.example: Buying $100,000 worth of a token in a small liquidity pool might cause 5% price impact, meaning you pay 5% more than the starting price.

terms.definition: A sandwich attack occurs when a malicious actor places transactions before and after a victim's trade to profit from the price movement caused by the victim's transaction.
terms.short_definition: MEV attack that surrounds victim's trade with buy/sell orders
terms.example: An attacker sees your large buy order, front-runs with their own buy to push price up, then back-runs with a sell order after yours executes.

terms.definition: Front-running occurs when someone observes a pending transaction and places their own transaction with higher gas fees to execute first, profiting from the predictable price movement.
terms.short_definition: Executing ahead of another transaction by paying higher gas fees
terms.example: A bot sees your DEX trade in the mempool and submits the same trade with higher gas fees to execute first and profit from the price movement.

terms.definition: TWAP is the average price of an asset calculated over a specific time period, weighted by time. It's used by oracles and protocols to provide more stable, manipulation-resistant price feeds.
terms.short_definition: Average asset price calculated over time to resist manipulation
terms.example: Uniswap V2 provides TWAP oracles that average prices over the last hour to prevent flash loan price manipulation attacks.

terms.definition: Concentrated liquidity allows liquidity providers to allocate capital within custom price ranges rather than across the entire price curve, increasing capital efficiency and potential returns.
terms.short_definition: Providing liquidity within specific price ranges for higher efficiency
terms.example: In Uniswap V3, you can provide USDC/USDT liquidity only between $0.99-$1.01, earning more fees per dollar with concentrated exposure.

terms.definition: An order book is a real-time list of buy and sell orders for an asset, organized by price level. It shows market depth and liquidity, common in centralized exchanges but rare in DeFi AMMs.
terms.short_definition: Real-time list of buy and sell orders organized by price
terms.example: On Coinbase Pro, the ETH/USD order book shows all pending buy orders below current price and sell orders above current price.

terms.definition: Market depth refers to the market's ability to sustain large orders without significantly impacting price. Deep markets have high liquidity and low price impact for large trades.
terms.short_definition: Market's ability to handle large orders without significant price impact
terms.example: ETH/USDC has deep market depth on major exchanges, so trading $1M causes minimal price impact, unlike small altcoin pairs.

terms.definition: The bid-ask spread is the difference between the highest price buyers are willing to pay (bid) and the lowest price sellers are willing to accept (ask). Tighter spreads indicate better liquidity.
terms.short_definition: Difference between highest buy price and lowest sell price
terms.example: If ETH has a $1999 bid and $2001 ask, the spread is $2. AMMs don't have traditional spreads but equivalent concepts exist.

terms.definition: Trading volume is the total amount of an asset traded over a specific period. High volume indicates active trading and often better liquidity and price discovery.
terms.short_definition: Total amount of an asset traded in a given period
terms.example: If $100 million worth of ETH trades in 24 hours across all exchanges, that's the daily trading volume for ETH.

terms.definition: A limit order is an instruction to buy or sell an asset at a specific price or better. It only executes when the market reaches the specified price level.
terms.short_definition: Order to trade at a specific price or better
terms.example: A limit buy order for ETH at $1950 will only execute if ETH drops to $1950 or below.

terms.definition: A market order is an instruction to buy or sell immediately at the best available current price. It guarantees execution but not the exact price.
terms.short_definition: Order to trade immediately at current market price
terms.example: A market buy order for 1 ETH will purchase at whatever price sellers are currently offering, regardless of the exact amount.

terms.definition: A stop loss is an order that automatically sells an asset when its price falls to a predetermined level, limiting potential losses on a position.
terms.short_definition: Automatic sell order triggered when price falls to set level
terms.example: If you buy ETH at $2000 and set a stop loss at $1800, your position automatically sells if ETH drops to $1800.

terms.definition: A take profit order automatically sells an asset when its price rises to a predetermined level, securing gains on a profitable position.
terms.short_definition: Automatic sell order triggered when price rises to target level
terms.example: If you buy ETH at $2000 and set take profit at $2200, your position automatically sells when ETH reaches $2200.

terms.definition: Dollar cost averaging is an investment strategy of regularly purchasing fixed dollar amounts of an asset regardless of price, reducing the impact of volatility over time.
terms.short_definition: Regular fixed-dollar purchases regardless of price to reduce volatility impact
terms.example: Buying $100 worth of ETH every week regardless of price, accumulating more tokens when cheap and fewer when expensive.

terms.definition: An audit is a thorough security review of smart contract code by external experts to identify vulnerabilities, bugs, and potential attack vectors before deployment or after updates.
terms.short_definition: Security review of smart contract code to identify vulnerabilities
terms.example: Before launching, Uniswap V3 underwent multiple audits by firms like Trail of Bits and Consensys Diligence to ensure code security.

terms.definition: A rug pull occurs when developers abandon a project and run away with investors' funds, often by removing liquidity from DEXs or exploiting backdoors in smart contracts.
terms.short_definition: Scam where developers abandon project and steal investor funds
terms.example: A new DeFi token launches, attracts millions in liquidity, then developers remove all liquidity and disappear, leaving investors with worthless tokens.

terms.definition: An exit scam is when project founders disappear with investors' money after raising funds, either through ICOs, presales, or by draining protocol treasuries.
terms.short_definition: Founders disappearing with investor money after fundraising
terms.example: A project raises $10M through token sales, then founders delete social media accounts and transfer all funds to personal wallets.

terms.definition: A honeypot is a malicious smart contract designed to trap users' funds. It appears to allow profitable interactions but contains hidden mechanisms preventing fund withdrawal.
terms.short_definition: Malicious contract that traps user funds with hidden withdrawal restrictions
terms.example: A token allows you to buy but has hidden code preventing sells, or a contract appears profitable but reverts all withdrawal attempts.

terms.definition: An exploit is an attack that takes advantage of vulnerabilities in smart contracts or protocols to steal funds, manipulate prices, or disrupt operations.
terms.short_definition: Attack exploiting smart contract vulnerabilities to steal funds or cause damage
terms.example: The 2022 Wormhole exploit used a signature verification bug to mint 120,000 ETH illegitimately, draining the bridge's reserves.

terms.definition: Bug bounty programs reward security researchers for finding and responsibly disclosing vulnerabilities in protocols before they can be exploited maliciously.
terms.short_definition: Reward program for finding and reporting security vulnerabilities
terms.example: Immunefi hosts bug bounties where researchers can earn up to $1M+ for finding critical vulnerabilities in major DeFi protocols.

terms.definition: White hat hackers are ethical security researchers who identify vulnerabilities in protocols and report them responsibly to help improve security rather than exploit them.
terms.short_definition: Ethical hacker who finds vulnerabilities to improve security
terms.example: A white hat discovers a critical bug in a lending protocol and reports it privately to the team, potentially saving millions in user funds.

terms.definition: Flash loan attacks use uncollateralized loans to manipulate DeFi protocols, often involving price manipulation, arbitrage exploitation, or governance attacks within a single transaction.
terms.short_definition: Attack using flash loans to manipulate protocols for profit
terms.example: An attacker uses flash loans to manipulate an oracle price, borrow against inflated collateral, then repay the flash loan while keeping the stolen funds.

terms.definition: Slashing is a penalty mechanism in Proof of Stake networks where validators lose part of their staked tokens for malicious behavior, downtime, or protocol violations.
terms.short_definition: Penalty where staked tokens are destroyed for validator misbehavior
terms.example: An Ethereum validator that goes offline for extended periods or signs conflicting blocks can have part of their 32 ETH stake slashed.

terms.definition: Phishing attacks trick users into revealing private keys, seed phrases, or approving malicious transactions through fake websites, emails, or social media messages.
terms.short_definition: Deceptive attacks to steal private keys or trick users into malicious transactions
terms.example: A fake Uniswap website looks identical to the real one but steals your wallet connection details when you try to trade.

terms.definition: An order book is a real-time electronic list of buy and sell orders for an asset, organized by price level. It shows market depth and available liquidity at different price points.
terms.short_definition: Real-time list of buy and sell orders organized by price levels
terms.example: On a centralized exchange like Coinbase, the ETH/USD order book shows all pending buy orders below current price and sell orders above.

terms.definition: Market depth refers to the market's ability to sustain large orders without significantly impacting price. Deep markets have substantial liquidity available at various price levels.
terms.short_definition: Market's ability to handle large orders without significant price impact
terms.example: ETH has deep market depth, so trading $1M causes minimal price impact, unlike small altcoin pairs with shallow depth.

terms.definition: The bid-ask spread is the difference between the highest price buyers are willing to pay (bid) and the lowest price sellers are willing to accept (ask). Tighter spreads indicate better liquidity.
terms.short_definition: Difference between highest buy price and lowest sell price
terms.example: If ETH has a $1999 bid and $2001 ask, the spread is $2. AMMs don't have traditional spreads but have equivalent trading costs.

terms.definition: Trading volume is the total amount of an asset traded over a specific period, usually measured in USD value or number of tokens. High volume indicates active trading and better price discovery.
terms.short_definition: Total amount of an asset traded in a given time period
terms.example: If $500 million worth of ETH trades across all exchanges in 24 hours, that represents ETH's daily trading volume.

terms.definition: A limit order is an instruction to buy or sell an asset at a specific price or better. It provides price certainty but doesn't guarantee execution if the market doesn't reach the specified price.
terms.short_definition: Order to trade at a specific price or better
terms.example: A limit buy order for ETH at $1950 will only execute if ETH price drops to $1950 or below.

terms.definition: A market order is an instruction to buy or sell immediately at the best available current price. It guarantees execution but not the exact price, especially in volatile markets.
terms.short_definition: Order to trade immediately at current market price
terms.example: A market buy order for 1 ETH will purchase at whatever price sellers are currently offering, regardless of the exact amount paid.

terms.definition: A liquidity provider supplies assets to trading venues to facilitate trading. In DeFi, LPs deposit token pairs into AMM pools to earn trading fees and rewards.
terms.short_definition: Entity that supplies assets to facilitate trading and earn fees
terms.example: You become an LP by depositing equal values of ETH and USDC into a Uniswap pool, earning 0.3% of all trading fees.

terms.definition: A swap is the direct exchange of one cryptocurrency for another, typically executed through AMMs or DEX aggregators without requiring order books or counterparties.
terms.short_definition: Direct exchange of one cryptocurrency for another
terms.example: Swapping 1 ETH for 2,000 USDC on Uniswap using the protocol's automated market maker.

terms.definition: A decentralized exchange operates without central authority, allowing users to trade cryptocurrencies directly from their wallets through smart contracts and AMMs.
terms.short_definition: Exchange operating without central authority using smart contracts
terms.example: Uniswap and SushiSwap are popular DEXs where you can trade tokens directly from your wallet without creating accounts.

terms.definition: A centralized exchange is operated by a company that controls user funds and facilitates trading through traditional order books, requiring users to deposit funds and create accounts.
terms.short_definition: Company-operated exchange controlling user funds with order books
terms.example: Binance, Coinbase, and Kraken are major CEXs where you deposit funds to trade with better liquidity and user experience.

terms.definition: Routing is the process of finding the most efficient path for a trade across multiple liquidity sources to minimize costs and slippage, often used by DEX aggregators.
terms.short_definition: Finding optimal trading paths across multiple liquidity sources
terms.example: 1inch routes your ETH-to-USDC trade through multiple DEXs and pools to get the best possible price.

terms.definition: The constant product formula (x*y=k) is the mathematical model used by AMMs like Uniswap to automatically set prices based on token ratios in liquidity pools.
terms.short_definition: Mathematical formula (x*y=k) used by AMMs for automatic pricing
terms.example: In a ETH/USDC pool, if you buy ETH, the ETH amount decreases and USDC increases, maintaining the constant product while raising ETH's price.

terms.definition: Liquidity aggregation combines liquidity from multiple sources (DEXs, CEXs, pools) to provide better prices, reduce slippage, and improve trading execution for users.
terms.short_definition: Combining liquidity from multiple sources for better trading execution
terms.example: Aggregators like 1inch and Paraswap combine liquidity from Uniswap, SushiSwap, Balancer, and other DEXs for optimal trades.

terms.definition: Price oracles provide real-time external price data to smart contracts, enabling DeFi protocols to make decisions based on accurate market prices for lending, derivatives, and other applications.
terms.short_definition: Service providing real-time price data to smart contracts
terms.example: Chainlink price oracles supply ETH/USD prices to MakerDAO for determining collateral values and liquidation thresholds.

terms.definition: Leverage allows traders to control larger positions than their capital would normally allow by borrowing funds. In DeFi, leverage amplifies both potential gains and losses through borrowed capital.
terms.short_definition: Using borrowed funds to amplify trading position size and potential returns
terms.example: With 3x leverage, you can control $3000 worth of ETH with only $1000 of your own capital, amplifying both gains and losses by 3x.

terms.definition: Margin trading involves borrowing funds to trade larger positions than your account balance allows. Traders post collateral and can be liquidated if positions move against them significantly.
terms.short_definition: Trading with borrowed funds using collateral to control larger positions
terms.example: You deposit $1000 ETH as collateral and borrow $2000 USDC to buy more ETH, creating a leveraged long position that can be liquidated if ETH drops.

terms.definition: A delta neutral strategy aims to eliminate directional price risk by balancing long and short positions so that the portfolio's value doesn't change with small price movements in the underlying asset.
terms.short_definition: Strategy that eliminates directional price risk through balanced long/short positions
terms.example: Providing ETH/USDC liquidity while shorting ETH with perpetual futures to hedge against ETH price movements, earning fees while minimizing price exposure.

terms.definition: Perpetual futures are derivative contracts that track an underlying asset's price without an expiration date. They use funding rates to keep prices aligned with spot markets.
terms.short_definition: Derivative contracts that track asset prices without expiration dates
terms.example: Trading ETH perpetuals on dYdX allows you to go long or short ETH with leverage, paying or receiving funding rates based on market sentiment.

terms.definition: The funding rate is a periodic payment between long and short traders in perpetual futures markets to keep the contract price aligned with the spot price of the underlying asset.
terms.short_definition: Periodic payment between perpetual futures traders to maintain price alignment
terms.example: If ETH perpetuals trade above spot price, long positions pay short positions a funding fee every 8 hours to incentivize price convergence.

terms.definition: Derivatives are financial contracts whose value derives from underlying assets like cryptocurrencies, stocks, or commodities. In DeFi, they enable advanced trading strategies and risk management.
terms.short_definition: Financial contracts deriving value from underlying assets
terms.example: Options on ETH, perpetual futures, and synthetic assets are all derivatives that let you trade price exposure without owning the underlying ETH.

terms.definition: Options are derivative contracts that give the holder the right (but not obligation) to buy or sell an asset at a specific price before expiration. They're used for hedging, speculation, and income generation.
terms.short_definition: Contracts giving the right to buy/sell assets at specific prices before expiration
terms.example: Buying ETH call options for $2500 strike gives you the right to buy ETH at $2500 regardless of market price, while selling covered calls generates income.

terms.definition: A carry trade involves borrowing low-yield assets to invest in higher-yield assets, profiting from the interest rate differential while exposed to exchange rate risk.
terms.short_definition: Borrowing low-yield assets to invest in higher-yield ones for interest differential profit
terms.example: Borrowing stablecoins at 3% APR to lend other tokens at 8% APR, earning 5% spread while exposed to the borrowed token's price risk.

terms.definition: Basis trading exploits price differences between spot and futures markets by simultaneously buying one and selling the other, profiting as the basis (price difference) converges to zero at expiration.
terms.short_definition: Arbitrage strategy exploiting price differences between spot and futures markets
terms.example: If ETH futures trade at $2050 while spot is $2000, buy spot ETH and short futures, profiting $50 per ETH when they converge at expiration.

terms.definition: Grid trading is an automated strategy that places multiple buy and sell orders at regular price intervals, profiting from market volatility by buying low and selling high within a defined range.
terms.short_definition: Automated strategy placing multiple orders at price intervals to profit from volatility
terms.example: Setting buy orders every $50 below ETH's current price and sell orders every $50 above, automatically trading the range as price oscillates.

terms.definition: A governance proposal is a formal suggestion submitted to a DAO or protocol community for voting. Proposals can include parameter changes, protocol upgrades, treasury spending, or strategic decisions.
terms.short_definition: Formal suggestion submitted to DAO community for voting on protocol changes
terms.example: A proposal to change Uniswap's trading fee from 0.3% to 0.25% would need to be voted on by UNI token holders before implementation.

terms.definition: Quorum is the minimum number of votes or percentage of total voting power required for a governance proposal to be considered valid and binding.
terms.short_definition: Minimum voting participation required for proposal validity
terms.example: If a DAO requires 10% quorum and has 100M tokens, at least 10M tokens must participate in voting for the proposal to pass.

terms.definition: A timelock is a mechanism that delays the execution of approved governance proposals, giving the community time to review and potentially exit before changes take effect.
terms.short_definition: Delay mechanism between proposal approval and execution for community review
terms.example: Compound uses a 2-day timelock, meaning approved proposals wait 48 hours before execution, allowing users time to withdraw if they disagree.

terms.definition: Vote escrow allows users to lock tokens for extended periods to receive enhanced voting power and rewards. Longer lock periods typically provide more voting weight and benefits.
terms.short_definition: Locking tokens for extended periods to gain enhanced voting power and rewards
terms.example: Curve's veCRV system lets users lock CRV for up to 4 years, with longer locks providing more voting power and higher rewards from protocol fees.

terms.definition: Delegation allows token holders to assign their voting power to another party (delegate) who votes on their behalf, enabling more informed participation in governance.
terms.short_definition: Assigning voting power to another party to vote on your behalf
terms.example: If you hold UNI tokens but don't have time to research every proposal, you can delegate your voting power to a trusted community member or organization.

terms.definition: A treasury is a pool of funds controlled by a DAO or protocol, typically used for development funding, ecosystem growth, partnerships, and community incentives.
terms.short_definition: Pool of funds controlled by DAO for development and ecosystem growth
terms.example: Uniswap's treasury contains millions in UNI tokens and other assets, used to fund grants, partnerships, and protocol development through governance votes.

terms.definition: A snapshot is a specific block height at which token holdings are recorded for governance voting, preventing users from buying tokens just to vote and then immediately selling.
terms.short_definition: Recording token holdings at specific block height for fair governance voting
terms.example: A governance vote announces a snapshot at block 15,000,000, meaning only wallets holding tokens at that block can participate, preventing last-minute vote buying.

terms.definition: A governance attack occurs when malicious actors acquire enough voting power to pass harmful proposals, potentially draining treasuries, changing protocol parameters, or disrupting operations.
terms.short_definition: Malicious actors gaining voting control to pass harmful proposals
terms.example: An attacker could buy a large amount of governance tokens, propose to transfer all treasury funds to their address, and vote it through if they have majority control.

terms.definition: Total Value Locked (TVL) measures the total amount of assets deposited and locked in a DeFi protocol or across the entire DeFi ecosystem. It's a key metric for assessing protocol adoption and security.
terms.short_definition: Total amount of assets deposited and locked in DeFi protocols
terms.example: If Uniswap has $5 billion TVL, it means $5 billion worth of crypto assets are currently locked in Uniswap's liquidity pools.

terms.definition: A seed phrase is a series of 12 or 24 words that can restore access to your cryptocurrency wallet and all associated private keys. It's the master backup for your entire wallet.
terms.short_definition: Series of words that can restore access to your cryptocurrency wallet
terms.example: A typical seed phrase looks like 'abandon ability able about above absent absorb abstract absurd abuse access accident' - 12 randomly generated words.

terms.definition: A private key is a secret cryptographic key that gives you control over your cryptocurrency. It's used to sign transactions and prove ownership of funds associated with a specific wallet address.
terms.short_definition: Secret cryptographic key that controls your cryptocurrency
terms.example: Your private key is like a digital signature - it proves you own the funds at your wallet address and allows you to send transactions.

terms.definition: A cryptocurrency wallet is a software or hardware tool that stores your private keys and allows you to send, receive, and manage your cryptocurrency. It doesn't actually store coins, but provides access to them on the blockchain.
terms.short_definition: Tool for storing private keys and managing cryptocurrency
terms.example: MetaMask is a popular browser wallet that lets you interact with DeFi protocols, while Ledger is a hardware wallet for secure offline storage.

terms.definition: MetaMask is a popular browser extension and mobile wallet that allows users to interact with the Ethereum blockchain and DeFi applications. It manages private keys and facilitates transactions with dApps.
terms.short_definition: Popular browser wallet for interacting with Ethereum and DeFi
terms.example: You can connect MetaMask to Uniswap to swap tokens, or to Aave to lend your assets, all from your browser.

terms.definition: A decentralized application (dApp) is an application that runs on a blockchain network rather than centralized servers. dApps use smart contracts for their backend logic and typically have no single controlling authority.
terms.short_definition: Application running on blockchain rather than centralized servers
terms.example: Uniswap, Aave, and Compound are popular DeFi dApps that run entirely on Ethereum using smart contracts.

terms.definition: Know Your Customer (KYC) is a regulatory process requiring businesses to verify the identity of their clients. In crypto, some centralized platforms require KYC, while DeFi protocols typically operate without it.
terms.short_definition: Regulatory process requiring identity verification of customers
terms.example: Centralized exchanges like Coinbase require KYC verification before you can trade, but DEXs like Uniswap allow trading without identity verification.

terms.definition: Le rendement annuel en pourcentage (APY) reprsente le taux de rendement rel gagn sur un investissement, en tenant compte de l'effet des intrts composs. En DeFi, l'APY montre combien vous pouvez gagner annuellement en prtant, fournissant de la liquidit ou en stakant.
terms.short_definition: Le rendement annuel d'un investissement incluant les effets des intrts composs
terms.example: Un pool de liquidit offrant 15% d'APY signifie que votre investissement initial crotrait de 15% sur une anne avec composition.
risks: Perte impermanente pour les tokens LP

common_questions.question: Quelle est la diffrence entre APR et APY ?
common_questions.answer: L'APR montre les intrts simples tandis que l'APY inclut les effets de composition. L'APY est gnralement plus lev et plus prcis pour les rendements DeFi.

related_articles.title: Comment faire fonctionner les produits DeFinanciers pour vous
related_articles.description: Guide complet des stratgies de rendement DeFi et comprhension des retours

terms.definition: La perte impermanente se produit lorsque vous fournissez de la liquidit aux teneurs de march automatiss (AMM) et que le ratio de prix de vos tokens dposs change par rapport au moment o vous les avez dposs. La perte est 'impermanente' car elle ne devient permanente que lorsque vous retirez votre liquidit.
terms.short_definition: Perte temporaire subie par les fournisseurs de liquidit quand les prix des tokens divergent
terms.example: Si vous fournissez de la liquidit ETH/USDC  1 ETH = 2000$, mais que l'ETH monte  3000$, vous aurez moins d'ETH et plus d'USDC au retrait, ratant une partie des gains d'ETH.

common_questions.question: Comment minimiser la perte impermanente ?
common_questions.answer: Choisissez des paires stables, utilisez soigneusement les plages de liquidit concentre, ou considrez le staking unilatral au lieu de fournir de la liquidit  des paires volatiles.

related_articles.title: Comment faire fonctionner les produits DeFinanciers pour vous
related_articles.description: Comprendre les risques LP et les stratgies de rendement DeFi

terms.definition: Le yield farming est la pratique de dplacer des actifs crypto entre diffrents protocoles DeFi pour maximiser les rendements. Les farmers fournissent typiquement de la liquidit, prtent des actifs, ou stakent des tokens pour gagner des rendements sous forme d'intrts, de frais, ou de tokens de rcompense.
terms.short_definition: Stratgie de maximisation des rendements en dplaant des actifs entre protocoles DeFi
terms.example: Un yield farmer pourrait fournir de la liquidit ETH/USDC sur Uniswap, staker les tokens LP sur une plateforme de rcompenses, et utiliser les tokens gagns dans un autre protocole pour des rendements additionnels.

common_questions.question: Le yield farming est-il rentable ?
common_questions.answer: Le yield farming peut tre rentable mais implique des risques significatifs incluant les vulnrabilits de smart contracts, la perte impermanente, et les frais de gas levs. Le succs ncessite une recherche minutieuse et une gestion des risques.

related_articles.title: La Bote  Outils du Farming DeFinancier
related_articles.description: Guide complet des stratgies de yield farming, outils et meilleures pratiques

related_articles.title: Vaults : Investissement DeFi Simplifi ?
related_articles.description: Comprendre les stratgies de rendement automatises et les mcanismes de vaults

terms.definition: Le liquidity mining est un mcanisme o les utilisateurs fournissent de la liquidit aux changes dcentraliss ou protocoles de prt en change de rcompenses en tokens. C'est utilis par les protocoles pour amorcer la liquidit et distribuer des tokens de gouvernance aux utilisateurs.
terms.short_definition: Gagner des rcompenses en tokens en fournissant de la liquidit aux protocoles DeFi
terms.example: Compound distribue des tokens COMP aux utilisateurs qui apportent des actifs  leurs pools de prt, incitant l'apport de liquidit.

common_questions.question: Combien de temps durent les programmes de liquidity mining ?
common_questions.answer: Les programmes varient largement, de quelques semaines  des annes. Beaucoup de protocoles ajustent les rcompenses selon les besoins du protocole et les dcisions de gouvernance.

related_articles.title: La Bote  Outils du Farming DeFinancier
related_articles.description: Comprendre les programmes de liquidity mining et les mcanismes de rcompense

terms.definition: Un Teneur de March Automatis (AMM) est un type de protocole d'change dcentralis qui s'appuie sur des formules mathmatiques pour fixer le prix des actifs plutt que sur des carnets d'ordres. Les AMM permettent le trading sans permission en utilisant des pools de liquidit o les utilisateurs peuvent changer des tokens automatiquement.
terms.short_definition: change dcentralis utilisant des formules mathmatiques pour la tarification au lieu de carnets d'ordres
terms.example: Uniswap est un AMM o les utilisateurs peuvent changer ETH contre USDC directement depuis les pools de liquidit sans besoin de contrepartie.
risks: Risques pour les fournisseurs de liquidit

common_questions.question: Comment un AMM dtermine-t-il les prix ?
common_questions.answer: Les AMM utilisent des algorithmes comme x*y=k (produit constant) pour ajuster automatiquement les prix bass sur l'offre et la demande dans les pools de liquidit.

terms.definition: Une Organisation Autonome Dcentralise (DAO) est une organisation base sur la blockchain gouverne par des smart contracts et des dtenteurs de tokens plutt que par des structures de gestion traditionnelles. Les membres votent sur des propositions utilisant des tokens de gouvernance pour prendre des dcisions sur l'avenir du protocole.
terms.short_definition: Organisation base blockchain gouverne par les dtenteurs de tokens et smart contracts
terms.example: MakerDAO gouverne le protocole Maker, o les dtenteurs de tokens MKR votent sur les frais de stabilit, types de collatral, et autres paramtres du protocole.

common_questions.question: Comment participer  la gouvernance d'une DAO ?
common_questions.answer: Dtenir des tokens de gouvernance, rester inform des propositions, et voter sur les dcisions qui affectent l'avenir du protocole.

terms.definition: Un smart contract est un contrat auto-excutant avec des termes directement crits en code. En DeFi, les smart contracts excutent automatiquement les transactions lorsque des conditions prdtermines sont remplies, liminant le besoin d'intermdiaires.
terms.short_definition: Code auto-excutant qui fait automatiquement respecter les termes du contrat sur blockchain
terms.example: Le smart contract d'un protocole de prt liquide automatiquement les positions sous-collatralises sans intervention humaine.

common_questions.question: Les smart contracts peuvent-ils tre changs aprs dploiement ?
common_questions.answer: La plupart des smart contracts sont immuables une fois dploys, bien que certains incluent des mcanismes de mise  niveau contrls par la gouvernance ou des cls admin.

terms.definition: La Finance Dcentralise (DeFi) fait rfrence  une forme de finance base sur blockchain qui recre et amliore les systmes financiers traditionnels utilisant des smart contracts, supprimant les intermdiaires comme les banques et courtiers. Les applications DeFi fonctionnent sur des blockchains publiques et sont accessibles  tous.
terms.short_definition: Systme financier bas blockchain oprant sans intermdiaires traditionnels
terms.example: Vous pouvez prter de l'USDC sur Compound, emprunter contre de l'ETH sur Aave, et changer des tokens sur Uniswap - tout sans banques ni courtiers.

common_questions.question: Quels sont les principaux avantages de la DeFi par rapport  la finance traditionnelle ?
common_questions.answer: Accessibilit 24/7, accs sans permission, transparence, programmabilit, et gnralement de meilleurs rendements pour les utilisateurs.

terms.definition: Un stablecoin est une cryptomonnaie conue pour maintenir une valeur stable relative  un actif de rfrence, gnralement le Dollar US. Les stablecoins fournissent les bnfices des cryptos (transferts rapides, transfrontaliers) tout en minimisant la volatilit des prix.
terms.short_definition: Cryptomonnaie conue pour maintenir une valeur stable relative  un actif de rfrence
terms.example: L'USDC maintient une valeur de 1$ soutenue par des rserves en dollars, tandis que le DAI est dcentralis et soutenu par du collatral crypto.

common_questions.question: Quelle est la diffrence entre stablecoins centraliss et dcentraliss ?
common_questions.answer: Les stablecoins centraliss comme l'USDC sont soutenus par des rserves fiat, tandis que les dcentraliss comme DAI utilisent du collatral crypto et des algorithmes.

related_articles.title: La Carte du Maraudeur des Stablecoins Dcentraliss
related_articles.description: Analyse complte des mcanismes et designs de stablecoins dcentraliss

related_articles.title: Le stablecoin GHO d'Aave peut-il aider le protocole  crotre ?
related_articles.description: Plonge profonde dans le design de GHO et l'conomie des stablecoins

terms.definition: Un pool de liquidit est une collection de fonds verrouills dans un smart contract qui permet le trading dcentralis, le prt, et autres fonctions DeFi. Les utilisateurs contribuent des actifs aux pools et gagnent des frais des trades ou intrts des prts.
terms.short_definition: Smart contract contenant des fonds qui permettent le trading et prt dcentraliss
terms.example: Le pool ETH/USDC sur Uniswap contient  la fois ETH et USDC, permettant aux utilisateurs d'changer entre ces tokens tandis que les LP gagnent des frais de trading.

common_questions.question: Comment les fournisseurs de liquidit gagnent-ils de l'argent ?
common_questions.answer: Les LP gagnent des frais de trading (typiquement 0,3%) de chaque change, plus des tokens de rcompense potentiels des programmes de liquidity mining.

terms.definition: Le slippage fait rfrence  la diffrence entre le prix attendu d'un trade et le prix rellement excut. Il se produit quand il y a une liquidit insuffisante ou une haute volatilit, causant un mouvement de prix dfavorable pendant l'excution du trade.
terms.short_definition: Diffrence entre le prix de trade attendu et le prix d'excution rel
terms.example: Vous essayez d'acheter pour 10 000$ d'un token  100$, mais  cause du slippage, vous finissez par payer une moyenne de 102$ par token.

common_questions.question: Comment minimiser le slippage ?
common_questions.answer: Trader des montants plus petits, utiliser des paires liquides, dfinir une tolrance de slippage approprie, ou utiliser des agrgateurs qui trouvent les meilleures routes.

terms.definition: Les tokens de gouvernance donnent aux dtenteurs des droits de vote sur les dcisions de protocole telles que les changements de paramtres, mises  niveau, et gestion de trsorerie. Ils reprsentent le contrle dmocratique des protocoles dcentraliss et s'apprcient souvent avec le succs du protocole.
terms.short_definition: Token qui fournit des droits de vote sur les dcisions de gouvernance du protocole
terms.example: Les dtenteurs de tokens UNI peuvent voter sur les mises  niveau du protocole Uniswap, structures de frais, et propositions de dpenses de trsorerie.

common_questions.question: Les tokens de gouvernance ont-ils une valeur montaire ?
common_questions.answer: Oui, ils se ngocient sur les marchs et tirent leur valeur du succs du protocole et des flux de trsorerie futurs potentiels ou bnfices.

terms.definition: Les flash loans sont des prts non-collatraliss qui doivent tre emprunts et rembourss dans le mme bloc de transaction. Ils permettent des stratgies DeFi complexes comme l'arbitrage, liquidations, et changes de collatral sans ncessiter de capital initial.
terms.short_definition: Prt instantan non-collatralis qui doit tre rembours dans la mme transaction
terms.example: Un trader utilise un flash loan pour emprunter 1000 ETH, arbitrer les diffrences de prix entre changes, et rembourser le prt plus les frais - tout dans une transaction.

common_questions.question: Que se passe-t-il si je ne peux pas rembourser un flash loan ?
common_questions.answer: Toute la transaction s'annule, ce qui signifie que vous rcuprez vos fonds originaux mais payez les frais de gas pour la transaction choue.

terms.definition: Ethereum est une plateforme blockchain dcentralise et open-source qui permet la cration de smart contracts et d'applications dcentralises (dApps). C'est la blockchain principale pour les applications DeFi grce  sa programmabilit et son cosystme tabli.
terms.short_definition: Plateforme blockchain programmable qui alimente la plupart des applications DeFi
terms.example: La plupart des protocoles DeFi comme Uniswap, Aave, et Compound sont construits sur la blockchain Ethereum.

terms.definition: Le Taux Annuel Effectif (APR) reprsente le taux d'intrt annuel simple sans tenir compte de la composition. En DeFi, l'APR montre le rendement de base avant les effets de la composition.
terms.short_definition: Taux d'intrt annuel simple sans effets de composition
terms.example: Un pool de prt offrant 10% APR signifie que vous gagnez 10% par an en intrts simples.
